bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Richard B. Russell, April 16, 1956

div1.p: Hench wants to testify before the Committee on Armed Services regarding Lambert's inclusion on the Roll of Honor. He asserts Lambert deserves honor, but it should be distinct from the Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Richard B. Russell, April 16, 1956
div1.opener:
April 16, 1956
Senator Richard B. Russell
Committee on Armed Services
United States Senate
Washington, D. C.
My dear Senator Russell:
div1.p:
Thank you for your recent note in answer to my inquiry about H.R. 5590, the
bill to add the name of Mr. Gustaf E. Lambert to the Roll of Honor in con-
nection with the discovery of the cause and means of transmission of yellow
fever.

I would like very much to be privileged to testify before your committee. I
have known Mr. Lambert for a number of years as uncovering the unpublished
facts of the conquest of yellow fever has been an intense hobby of mine, or
an avocation, for the last fifteen years. I enclose two reprints. I have
studied every phase of the work of Walter Reed and his colleagues and the
work of Finlay. I have visited the homes of practically all the survivors and
the families of the yellow fever participants who are no longer living have
honored me by making me the repository of a very large amount of unpublished
material.

I think I am therefore quite familiar with the contribution of Mr. Lambert. I
have visited his home and he has been a guest in my home. I am very anxious to
honor him and he deserves much. I would certainly go to the expense of going
to Washington to testify before the Committee in his behalf; however I want to
see that Mr. Lambert is honored appropriately.

Please consider this letter an informal one and I would prefer that it not be
considered a part of your official data with respect to this bill. The reasons
are these: Although Mr. Lambert deserves great honor and has been neglected,
and although I am most anxious to help him get an appropriate honor from Congress,
his honor should be distinct from that of the Roll of Honor. Actually, Mr.
Lambert did not volunteer directly for the yellow fever experiments and his
connection with the yellow fever patients began when, sometime before Walter
Reed's commission began their work, Mr. Lambert volunteered to Doctor Ames to
help care for yellow fever patients and other patients at another location in
Havana.

Later, when it become necessary to care for patients with spontaneous yellow
fever at the little hospital across the railroad track from the Post Hospital
at Camp Columbia, Lambert and Doctor Ames merely transferred their activities
there and then, of course, when the victims of experimental yellow fever needed
care, these two men - the doctor and the nurse - took care of them too. Thus
Senator Richard B. Russell - 2 - April 16, 1956
Mr. Lambert, up to that time, was merely doing his duty. He did wonderful
work but it was done in line of duty; however he did it with such zeal that as far
as he was concerned he might be said to have served beyond the reasonable limits
of his duty. Nevertheless, the distinction should be maintained, I believe, in be-
half of these who actually and “officially” volunteered. By that I mean the
following: When General Wood gave Major Reed permission to call for volunteers,
this information was spread among the soldiers at Camp Columbia Post Hospital
by word of mouth. Presumably not only Doctor Ames but the other medical officers
spoke to the soldiers who served them in the hospital and all of whom were poten-
tial volunteers. We do not know to whom each man actually volunteered first
but of course eventually they must have been interviewed by Reed himself. We
know that Kissinger and Moran went to Reed and volunteered although each first
heard of the proposition from Doctor Ames.

Now there is no place in the official record, that is the official papers or
the later writings of any member of the Yellow Fever Board, where it states
that Lambert volunteered, at least to Reed: nor have I found any written
record that Lambert did actually volunteer to Doctor Ames for the specific
experiments of Reed. I have many letters that he wrote to Generals Truby and
Kean and to some of the enlisted men he knew, such as Tate, Andrus and so on,
letters written long after the events of 1900. It is my distinct recollection
that nowhere in the earlier of these letters did Mr. Lambert claim to have
volunteered for Reed's experiments. I interviewed Mr. Lambert on two or three
occasions and the same holds true for my interviews. It was only later that
he mentioned, almost as an afterthought, that he had volunteered to Doctor
Ames and he described the occasion of his volunteering.

Doctor Ames one day, very early in the days of Camp Lazear, told Lambert to hop
into the Beherty wagon and they drove over to Camp Lazear on an errand of Ames'.
Ames did not let Lambert leave the wagon. Then they went back to the yellow
fever huts. During the ride Ames must have mentioned the volunteers and the
money each was to get and Lambert made a remark that seems rather casual that
he would just as soon volunteer for a little extra money, but Ames did not
encourage him to do it, presumably because Ames needed Lambert to continue
nursing at the yellow fever huts. Now if Lambert had been really serious
about volunteering, even if only for the sake of the money, he could have
taken the matter up again with Ames or he could have passed the word to Reed
and asked that he be given this chance. There is no record anywhere, including
the many statements by Lambert, that he did this. In other words, apparently
this is the only time and these are the circumstances under which Lambert did
“volunteer” and certainly it would not appear that even if he did make this
remark to Ames that he did it with any idea of rendering service to medicine
or the medical corps.

There is no question but that Mr. Lambert has a compulsive nature and that he
carried out his duties with Doctor Ames at the yellow fever huts with unusual
devotion, one might say extra-ordinary devotion. Apparently he was determined
to do the job and to do it alone. He stayed there night and day and nursed
practically all of the volunteers alone and for this he deserves great credit.

Now, actually in 1929, when Congress passed the bill honoring certain volunteers,
it did not include the Spanish volunteers nor did it include even some of the
American volunteers who did not get experimental yellow fever for one reason or
another. As I understand it, Congress honored only three groups: (1) the four
Senator Richard B. Russell - 3 - April 16, 1956
members of the Yellow Fever Commission, for obvious reasons; (2) the volunteers
who exposed themselves to the filth of the fomites building and (3) the other
volunteers at Camp Lazear who got experimental yellow fever, but not those who
did not get it, even though they did everything that was asked of them, had the
presumably infected mosquitos placed on their bodies and faced, psychologically,
the same uncertainties as did the others. Another men who deserves great credit,
perhaps more than any other man except those already honored, was Doctor Ames
himself, the doctor who actually took care of the experimental cases. Would it
not be ironic to have Congress now honor the male nurse and not honor the doctor
who was in charge of all these experimental cases? Would it not be inappropriate
to honor a man who, by the Army's viewpoint, merely served excellently (I would
say magnificently) but only within the limits of his duty and not honor those
who volunteered with full knowledge that they might not only get yellow fever,
indeed probably would, but might actually die but who, for some reason not of
their own doing (the mosquitos might not have been ripe) did not develop yellow
fever? To honor Mr. Lambert now, largely because he is living, and to ignore
his chief and the others who actually volunteered but whose results were nega-
tive would be to put a premium on simple longevity and not to assess the contri-
bution that these various man made. To honor Lambert now and not to honor
Doctor Ames would be making the same distinction (merely that one is alive and
the other not) that would have been made had Congress decided to honor Reed,
Carroll and Agramonte and not to honor Lazear who died of the experiments.

I agree heartily that Congress should “clean this thing up” and correct any re-
mote injustice but they should not accomplish another injustice in order to honor
one man. Therefore I have a proposal which seems better to me. The service
of Doctor Lazear was a very fundamental one. At the one point of time during
which Major Reed was called to Washington for special duty, Lazear actually
held the fate of the experiments in his hands and it was during Reed's un-
fortunate absence that Lazear's first experiments became positive and then
apparently the fatal experiment of Lazear on himself. Reed had to return and
had to develop the later series of experiments because the first report, based
largely on the experiments of Lazear, received no more acceptance from the
American or general public than did the early reports of Finlay. Therefore
although it might be said that Lazear was actually the first one to discover
and prove the cause of yellow fever and passed on his discovery to Reed by
way of the little pocket notebook, nevertheless Reed had to re-prove it in
a way that the world would accept. Thus no one should try to, or can, de-
prive Reed or the other men of one bit of their credit, but Lazear certainly
deserves more than he over got and of course he didn't get any recognition
because he died.

My proposition, therefore, is as follows: For Congress to pass a new bill, or
on amendment to the old bill, and create perhaps a new medal, giving let us say
the Lazear Medal to Mr. Lambert (alive) and to Doctor Ames posthumously, and to
the volunteers who actually went through the experiments but did not get yellow
fever. There would be no pensions involved and in that way Congress would re-
tain the all-important distinction made on the occasion of its 1929 action.

I think you would agree that were this situation as of today and were it polio
instead of yellow fever, one would have to make a distinction between our
respect and regard for doctors or nurses who, thinking little or nothing of
their own safety, took care of polio patients at some risk, and volunteers who
Senator Richard B. Russell - 4 - April 16, 1956
actually submitted themselves, at the risk of life, to polio inoculations of
live virus. In my opinion, Doctor Ames and Mr. Lambert stand at the head
of the first group but with all due regard to their magnificent contribu-
tions, they do not belong to the second group where Congress contemplates
placing them.

My distress about all of this is that I do have great admiration for Mr.
Lambert. I have tried to help him get recognition by writing to him and
he is to have an appropriate and honored part in my book. He is old and
feeble and crippled and almost blind, a rather pathetic but nevertheless
proud and worthy figure. I hate terribly to do anything that might hold up an
honor to him so that it would come too late, after he passed on. I would
almost rather see Congress make a mistake and include him in the old bill,
even though this is a real injustice to his chief, Doctor Ames, and to
the other volunteers who were excluded. Fortunately, that is not my de-
cision to make but if I thought that I could help Congress, specifically
you and your committee colleagues, to write what I believe would be the
proper bill and pass it quickly; if I thought that appearing before your
committee and perhaps a committee of the House would accomplish this, this year,
I would certainly be delighted to do whatever I can.

In view of the above, will you please, therefore, let me know whether you
could hear me testify and present such documentary proof as I have (it is
voluminous and would have to be summarized carefully, not a job that could
be done over night), and when that might be. I have been invited to give
two lectures at Johns Hopkins Medical School, May 9 and 10, and could arrange
to visit Washington during that week. I am leaving now to attend the meetings
of the American College of Physicians at Los Angeles, and will not be back until
April 28.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
